div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Next Friday afternoon the new Ghizeh boys bagpipes band will perform in the Zoological Gardens, Ghizeh, Oairo.
There are. now twelve cases’ of bubonic plague under treatment, two fresh cases and two deaths ‘are reported from Deirout.
A Sudanese was run over yesterday hy a train, near Khorshid, Ramleh, and“ received such serious injuries that he succunibed shortly. afterwards.
Colonel E.A. Herbert M.V.O. is appointed President, Gaptain W. R. Eden, D8 0., Secret- ary, and Captain Duffus, Treasurer, of the ‘Cairo military tournament committee.

The transport 8.8./‘Sudan’” is due to avtive in Egypt about the 30th inst. with the Yorkshire Regiment and details. The 2nd Battalion In- niskilling Fusiliers will embark on the 2nd prox. for England.
A merchants committee has been organized at. Omdurman, consisting ofsome ofits leading merchants, for the purpose Of looking after the nterests of trade in that city.
Five fresh cases and fifty-two deaths. from cholera occurred at Mecca on the 2nd inst.eight deaths occurred onthe same day at Djeddah, one fresh case being brought up for treatment at the same town.

At ameeting of the ‘Alexandria Stock and Sharebrokers held yesterday it was decided to found an association for the protection of Egyptian shareholders. The full details will be found in: the financial portion of to-day’s . issue.

The Anntal Khartoum District Miltary tournament took place on the race course at Khartoum on Saturday week. The events that * took place testify to the efficiency of the troops and the ability and skill of their officers.

The corner stone of the Evangelical Church’ building at Khartoum was laid on Saturday week. At6 p.m. a service was held at the present meeting house for the ordination of the newly elected elders and deacons of the Church.

Our Snez correspondent- states that the Dutch Mail boat “Konig Wilhelm III,” which bad-been ashore in the small lakes in the Suez “Caual, has been successfully refloated, after baving diecharged in lighters several hundred tons of general cargo, which she started to | take in on Friday ‘at the Port Tewfik moorings.

Recently “an: interesting work, entitled “Things Seen in Egypt” was published by Messrs. Seeley & Co., in London and was very favourably reviewed. The author @as Mr. Clive Holland. The book has had to be withdrawn because of copyright matter having been un- intentionally made use of from Mr. Talbot Kelly’s “Egypt,”

The Egyptian State Railways have the honour to inform the public ‘that owing to the running of 4 new passenger train between Alexandria and El-Emaid (M@fiout Railway) from 1st January, the: timings of opéning Nouzha Bridge will be modified as follows : from 6.10 aim. up to 7.10a.m., from 9.40 a.m. up to 11,20 em, to from 3.35 p.m. up 4,3 p.m.

div.head: CASSA DI-SCONTO.
div.p: The third sitting of the” Mixed Commercial ‘Court at Alexandriavin the case of Azmy Bey v. ' the Cassa di Sconto began this morning, and the Court rose at 1.20 p.m. Almost all the sit- ting was oocupied with the pleading of Maitre Lebsohu. Maitre Mercinier and Maitre Padoa Bey also spoke.
The farther hearing: of the case wae ad journed for a week when the conclusions of the Ministere Public will be heard.

Towards the close of -to-day’s sittings the lawyers had a hot discussign. Maitre Le¥sohu declared, among other interesting things, that ‘half of the bank’s liabilities had already been * realised. He also said that the shares could be paid off above their par value.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY- CONNEL BEY’S ‘RETIREMENT.
div.p: The Sirdar wishes to express his regret at the retirement from the Egyptian Army of E Miralai J. R. O’Connel Bey, who has serve for over 10 years with His Highness The Khe dive’s troops, during which period he has held the appointments of Officer Commanding, 2n¢ Battalion, and Governor and Officer Comman ding Troops, Kordofan Province.
El Miralai-O’Connell Bey took part in th following campaigns and actions in whch th Egyptian Army has been engaged :—
Expedition to Dongola, 1896. — Actions 0 Firket and Hafir.
Nile Expedition, 1898.—Battle of Khartoun and Relief of Gedaref
Nile Expedition, 1899-
Sudan, 1906.— Operations in Southern Kor dofan.—Talodi.

The Sirdar desires to express his apprecié tion of the valuable services rendered by } Miralai O’Connel Bey, and 6n bebalf & ranks of the Egyptian Army to wish him speedy return to heslth and every success | the future,
MENELIK’S DEMANDS REFUSED.
London, Monday

The “Morning Post” says that the Sultan | has issued a decree refusing absolutely to grant the Abyssinian demands relating to religious questions in Palestine. He desires to be agree- bie in his wishes towards Menelik; but finds it necessary to ‘avoid any thing which might tend to embitter the relations between the Churches of Syria.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will leave Alexandria’ this evening for Cairo.

Mustaphe Pasha Ibady, Governor of Alex- andria will hold an official reception at the Governorat, on the 8thinst., from 10 a.m. to 12; in honour of the Kh edive’s accession: fate. His Excellency has issued iny itations to anum ber of high officials and notables of Alexandria td a banquet, which will be givén in the even- ing of that day at the New Khedivial Hotel.

Cairo is rapidly assuming a very festive ap- pearance for the celebration of the anniversary ‘Vof the Khedive’s acoesgion. The whole length of the route from the station to the Abdin end of Opera Square is already fitted with poles carrying strings of electric fairy lamps ‘across the street, while nnmerons other schemes of decoration are also in progress.
The following interesting piece of informa- | tion appears-in the “Arte” of Cairo-: —

“ Lorsque lord Cromer projetait de visiter les provinces égyptiennes, il donnait ses ordres aux ministres et aux mona directement. Sir E. Gorst y met itfiniment plus de tormes, il s’adresse au Khédive et demande “si Son Altesse verrait ‘quelque inconvénient & ce qu’il se rendit dans Jes provinces pour se rendre compte de la sitnation ”. De cette facon, les susceptibilités d’en haut sont ménagées et les populations en'tressaillent dé joie.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The Council of Mites will’ meet on Tharsday next at Abdeen Palacé Cairo, under thie ‘presidency of the Khedive.

div.head: A BATCH OF MURDERS.
div.p: A murder was committed yesterday evening at about’? o'clock in-the open spacein which Ribero’s circus is situated at Alexandria.” A :| Berberine, who is said to“have been drunk, was attacked by a Greek, a local subject, with -|@ ragor, with such force that his head was almost severed from his body. Both men were of bad character and the quarrel is said to have been die to thé lowest form of vice.

A brutal attempt at murder was made on Saturday at Port Said by Georges Vidanoff on his nephew Damiam Ivanoff, the men being joint managers of the Pilsner Bierhalle. The inotive appears to have Leen a question of jealousy cause‘ by a broken engagement with a cousin. The men lived in ‘the same room and upon Damian entering the rodnr his uncle plunged a’ knife into hjs left lung. The ‘wounded man was able to leave his room and seck first’ aid at a neighbouring *phar l‘macy, from where he was ‘transferred to hospital. Georges Vidanoff, who tried to escape, has been captured by the police.
Our Santa correspondent writea :—

A well-known thiet has just been murdered in this neighbourhood. He was a native of the Gharbieh province and in spite of having often been caught, he was trequently acquitted by the courts. On the principle of setting a thief tocatch a thief he was appointed by the Government Sheikh Ghaffir of Shubra Kala district of the Santa Markaz. He was wurdered while on night duty on Friday by an unknown person, who shot him fall if the breast. The |: murderer is said to be one of the victims of his depredations,

Zaki Arditti, a Manedarah chemist, was murdered by an onknown - individual while opening his shop two days ago, & knife being plunged into: his heart. The motive is quite unknown,gpnd great sorrow at so tragic an end to Aiditi’s life is expressed by all. He wasa good friend to the poor, whom he often treated gratuitously.

The frost has broken and a general thaw set in.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON.
div.p: “Thais” is full of the usual Massenet charac- teristics, his ‘sensuous’ delicacy and melodious continuity into which break nowandagain points ofirony: this last feature was, as in his “Jon- gleur de Notre Dame,” most marked in’ his treatment of the Monastic- and conventical scenes. Somehow to me certain phases of, for instance, the ‘Meditation” had a slightly Italian flavour, and lacked the light grace so notable in the rest of the Opera. ‘That ‘“Medi- tation” was ;by the way, beautifully played by. M. Martellini, his tone saggested all the soft caressing mystery of Thais, herself—or Mile Genevois as Thais, for that matter: for she was, charming; ‘her voice and technique were. Linstinct with variety, cleat, and faultless. Her invocation to Venus was really excellent. M. de Ryle regained his lost prestige, and) sang quite well throughout. M. Vernet had little enough to do, but gave the impression that the part did not really suit him. The chorus was not q ‘ite 80 good as usaal: there were occasional lapses of decision-in the malé voices. The orchestra was excellent, as was M. Baron, but he occasionally seem’ to lose the sense of the movement of the music, to become slightly professorial.

div.head: THE SAVOY.
div.p: Some evil sprite must have got mistaken in the calendar this last week, and mistaken the ist January for the Ist April. Wedo not know how originated the rumour that the Empre Eugenie had arrived in Cairo: but it was substantiated. sufficiently to appear in print, with the result that the Savoy was besieged by all the notables of the place all ahxious to pay their devoirs to the august visitor. Hardly had this rumour collapsed than another was set going to the effect thatthe Savoy was on the eve of closing ite~teors, presdmably ‘from disappointment that the Empress was not within them. This also Aurney out , to bea canard of the most onwarrantable kind. Fat from shutting its doors, the Savoy is preparing many new rooms for the accumodation: of the many guests who are expected within the next few days. Numberless are the applications that have Been received of late :. there have been no less than seven for the suite of apart- ments which aré being reserved for Sir Ernest ‘Cassel and his party; and there are many evidences to prove that even if the season has tarried long in its coming it is going to be gay while it lasts.

There was the usual festive air abont the hotel on Saturday when dinner parties. were the order of the night, and the usual dance : attracted all the usual people and various of the new comers. Count Kodzibrodzki had: ‘as guests the Marquis de Fioravanti, Baron de Villenfangue, Dr,’ Wagner and othdrs: Miss Cochrane's -party of ten included” Major and} {Mra de Lobinitre, Colonel. Harvey Pasha, S02 a a @orneeo Major Hoskins. Mr. and Mrs. Fraser, Mrs. Gye and Mrs Maclean. Captain and Mra. Darrell entertained a party of eight, among whom were Major Neil Haig, Major J. Pon- sonby and Captain A. M. Mc Murdo. Lieut. Orred’s table was graced by the presence of Miss Fitzclarence, his fiancée, Mr. Mortimer had a party of sixaud with Mr. T. BE. Pooley were Miss Rees, Captain A: B. Bethel and Captain W.R. Eden. Mr. and Mrs Oatley were entertaining guests, as also were Dr, Lahnsteiv, Captain Nixon, Captain Dawson, Lieut. Buxton, and Mr. Reyntien. Over se- venty people occupied the restaurant at. sup- per tine. Mra. de B. Carey entertaining party of eight, which included Princess Irene Duleep Singh and Mme. Cattani. “Mr, Suares and. others being noticed at a large table with fourteen guests. Space forbids a detailed account of the dance which was as | fully successfal as any of its predecessors.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss Liner ‘“Rameses” sailed on Satu afternoon last for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 4,852 bales of cotton.

div.head: AN HYSTERICAL WOMAN’S HATRED.
div.p: Berlin, January 5:

The entire Press. approves the judgment in the Harden case and points out that accusa- tions: which brought. misfortnne on private individeals and the whole German people were only founded on the hatred df an hysterical woman, who heraelf declared she was not in a condition to speak the truth. :Every one is content that the judgment energetically pro- tests against a political system, hitherto unknown in Germany, which attacks political men by libelling them and by recounting stories of intimate’ relations.
The same individuals who asserted that crimes committed by certain personages were known to every one were unable to prove any ink: Count: Moltke’s honour is therefore Rotts -coaane sane ‘ (Reuter)

div.head: THE SUDAN BUDGET.
div.p: A comparative aioe of the Sudan Govern- ment Reports brings out many interestings facts, says the “Sudan Times,” and indicates the rapid strides of progress, at which the country has beén advancing. In 1900, when Sir R.F. Wingate assumed the administration of the Government of the Sudan, the refe- ‘nue of the country did not exceed LE. 150,000. In the budget for 1908, the revenue is estimated at L.E. 1,000,000. In’ other words, in the’ period of seven years the revenue has increased sevenfold which is a very remarkable development.
In 1905, the revenue from the land tax, inclusive otusbur, was about LE. 30,000. In the budget for 1908, this source: of revenue is estimated at about LE. 100,000.
These figures need no comment. They testify to theable financial management of the coun- try, and to the wholesome general admitiistra- tration, which. has rendered such sncoéss possible.

Among other interesting facts in the Sudan Budget, we.notice that the revenue of the Sudan Government Railways for 1908 is esti- mated’ at L. E 300,000. It is anticipated that the revenue for the present year, 1907, will reach the figure of L. E. 300,0°:0 against an es- timate of L.E. 250,00). The revenue for 1905, prior to. the construction of the Nile Red-Sea | Railway, was only L.E, 171,000. These figures are aii eloquent testimony to the remarkable development of trade and to the benefits result- } ing from the construction of this line, which | connects the interior of the country with its natoral outlet.

We have no definite idea of the capital ex- pended on the constraction of the Sudan Rail-. ays, bat we have no doubt, judging by the re- ! markable progress already alluded to, ‘that in | | time considerable profit will be realized over | these lines to compensate the fovernment for the cost of construction: -

We understand, farther, that the Director of Railways is making every possible endeayour to reduce charges for freight. We have réferred in these-columns to the reductions already An- nounced, and we learn, in addition, that a spe- cial reduction has been granted for full track loads on goods destined. to Dongola Province.

div.head: PORT, SAID STRIKE ENDED.
div.p: (FRoM OUR OWN # CORRESPONDENT),
Port Said, Sunday.

The coal bischarging and bunkering Arabs who have been out on strike since December 19th returned to wirk yesterday afternoon. On Saturday morning a thousand odd coolies came down ‘from the Arab town with their skeikhs and asked the masters what arrange- ment they would make. About‘10 a.m. the sheiks reported that thé men were ready to tesume work under the old agreement. The Masters: met in counsel and it ‘was decided that the men should be called down as,soon as the “black legs” had left the ships. At 11 a.m. everything was ready for the men to \resume work, but in answer to the first call orily 30 men pot in an appearance and it was not till‘after 5 p.m. that a proper start was made. To-day the men baye worked when watited and it is considered that the stnke is ovér. There are now some 30 or 35 vessels in port discharging coal.

div.head: NEWS FROM THE LEBANON.
div.p: We learn from the Lebanon that the Admin- istrative Council there, which, met on the 28th ulto. under the presidency of the Mutassarrif, bas decided to impose new taxes on the Lebanese, to the amouut of LE. 3,500, witha view to increase the salaries of the civil officials -of Mutasarrifiat.
Youssef Franco Pasha has also appointed new inspectots for the hill-country imposing a tax of 8 mejidiehs (Tarkish dollars) on each, per annum inorder to cover the expenses of the new posts.

div.head: AT THE SEAMEN’S HOME.
div.p: On Monday last the, annua! entertainment was given to the sailors in the port-of Alex- andrier when about 250 sat down to a splendid repast provided for them-by Lady Blomfield and her friends. The sailors thoroughly enjoyed themselves and did justice to everything provided for them, after which tobacco was served to each, the present of the Consul- General, alsé a Christmas card to each one present. The tables having been cleared and the hall arranged for a concert the musical portion commenced, aid we were pleased to note among those present Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, Mr. E B: Gould, 18.0, Consul-General, and Mrs.,Gould,. Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Archdeacon and Mrs. Ward and Mrs. Macaulay, Mr.\and Mrs. R. 8 Preston, Mr. Macaulay, R.N. and Mr. T. C. Macaulay. ‘Mr. 0.8. Heaton, opened witha pianoforte solo: followed by Mr..Hugh. Blomfield. who gave.4 violin solo which was, greatly appreciated, also a second song. Mra W.F. Sarjeant.sang “May. Day’sin'a manner which 20 pleased the sudience that she was. compelled to‘give> an encote and in the second part also sang two songs with much taste. Mrs. Roberts gaye a render- ing, of Cowen’s. beautiful song “The Children’s Home” and “The Better Land” Mr.: AS. Preston, delighted. all’ with- the well-known recitation by G.R: Sims “T'was Christmas Day, in the workhouse.” Mr. Haydn Righton gave a pianoforte solo, very well rendered - and also. accompanied many in their songs. The chief delight to the ters was, however, Mr. Tookey who gave two humorous songs in the first: part and three in the second, and the last song, ‘The British Navy,” was joined in by the tars in such away ‘as only British: sailors can do. St. Mark’s Choir ‘also obliged with two appro priate Christmas carols.

At the conclusion of a most suecessful even- ing. Mr. E.B- Gould, referting in glowing to the work Sit Massieand Lady Blomfield had dene for the Seamen’s Home, paid great tribute to thefactthat Sir Massie was practical- ly the father and originator of the Home, and although this would be the last occasion on -which he would preside,"Mr. Gould wished him in the name of all present many happy years in his future home in the Old Country which he sorichly deserved. The Ven. Archdea- con Ward supported Mr. Gould in most. eulogistic: terms and expressed his personal regret at losing Sir Massie and Lady Blomfi- eld from Aléxandria. Sir Massie, who was received’ with loud cheers, commenced his reply with “Ladies and gentlemen and brother tars,” and expressing his deep thanks to Mr. Gould and-all present: for the way his name had been mentioned and received, refused to take the praise oftered to him as it was but chiefly due to the untiring efforts ot his wife, Lady Blomfield, that the Home. had been founded. They had always taken a deep in- terest in it and in their future honie in England : ‘the Seamens Home at Alexandria would always | have a warm corner in their hearts He also | thanked Mr. W. F. Sargeant for the organisa- tion of thé musical programme. Three cheérs were then given for Sir Massie and taken up by every one in the hall, then three loud cheers for Lady Blomfield after which the singing of “God Save the King” brought a memorable and most successful evening to a close.

div.head: LUXOR WINTER PALACE.
div.p: Ideal weather, a luxurious hotel with all concerned in the management bent on giving their clientile the best of’ good times, and & coutingent of visitors equally bent on making the most of their Christmas holiday, all com- bined to make the first Christmas that the Winter Palace has seen a huge success. Over 100 people ‘had assembled .in the hotel by Christmas Eve, when a small dance was giver as a sort of foretaste of things to come the next day. These numbers were largely increased by the’ two large tourist steamers and the numerous private steamers and dahabeahs moored in front of the town-so that Luxor seems to have suddenly awakened from her long summer sleep, and to find herself once more in the fall swing of a season that pro- mises to be a very good one,

Amongst other well known people who are spending Christmas here are Count von Bernstorff and family, Mr. and Mrs. Iddings and party, Mr. Russell Res, M-P., and party, the Hon. E. Gibbs and party, the Earland Countess of -Rothes, Sir Barrington Simeon, Mr. Clapodte, Dr. ‘Sinclair Thompson, Colonel Eden, and Capt. W. Eden, Mr. Theodore Davis and party, Mr. and Mrs Sprot, Sir M. Mc- Ilwraith, Dr. Granville, etc. ;

Morning service in the little English church >| was well attended, the singing was specially hearty, and the Luxor Hospital for natives S| benefited to the extent of over £7 by. the collection. After lunch a, gymkhana took place i | in the garden of the hotel which, thanks to the Bl energy of the promotors, especially Mr. Mooijaart, Mr. Pearson. (of the Railway Admi- '\nistration) and Mrs. Pennell, was a most successfal affair. The race were entered into with a great deal of spirit.

The events were : - (1) Chalking the line, won by Mr: Simpson, and Captain Hughes second ; (2) Needle-threading race, won by, Miss Wanklyn; (8) Hopping race, won by Mr. Vaquhart, and Mr. Mooijaart second; (4) Blind-fold driving race, won by, Mme Slatzh | and Mr. Losco, and Miss‘ G@ Wanklyn’and Mr. Pennell second ; (5) Arabic race, won by, Mra. Simpson and Mrs. Mackell second ; (6) Whist- ling race, won by, Mr. Urquhart, and Mr. Losco second.
The dinner, to which; about 150, guests sat down, was a triumph ot ménage, and reflected

the greatest credit on all concerned in it. The chef of the Winter Palace has.e. reputation all - over Egypt, and it may be said that he sur-’ passed himeelf,on this occasion, ee the actual dishes, but. in the dainty and ~ original manner in which things were served. . In a word, everything was perfect, down to the menu card which formed « pleasing sou- venir of the cocasion:

After dinner everyone assembled in the lounge, where a ‘fine Christmas tree, most tastefully decorated and lighted, had been placed, and here the prizes were distributed tothe lucky: winners in the gymikhans. ~In- claded in theses was a bottle of champagne, kindly «given by. the -management for the whistling race, and this was borne off, a he great epplause, by Mr. A. Urquhart presentation was gracefully performed by Countess Bernsdorff, and Mr. Pearson made an excellent little speech) which finished by an- nouncing that the hospital had again benefit- ed by the amusement, of the afternoon.
The Christmas dance then started, - and was kept up with spirit.and enjoyment, to the catuiein eaighe p fiiee anling 2 toa | Shortly enjoyable Ohrictoms’ y:

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: On the 27th inst. a Reuter’s telegram from Paris announced that the Empress Eugenie had: left Marseilles for Egypt and recently a Cairo contemporary stated that the Empress -had arrived at the Savoy Wotel, Cairo. The fact'is that the Empress: only stopped for a short time at: Port Said. last reek on her way out to Ceylon, where she. will be the guest of Sir Thomas Lipton as we announced on Friday _ last. London newspapers speak of the Empress as having embarked for-Egypt and the mistake appears to have been general. On her retarn from Ceylon some weeks will be spent at Cap Martin before she returns to England. *

The Sirdar and Lady Wingate held a recep - tion on Chritmas night, at ‘which ‘a large ‘number of distinguished, guests attended, including Mr. Winston \Charchill and party. Dancing and music were aie in until a late hour.

The next day afterthe arrival of Mr. Winston Churchill at _Khartoom. his valet, — who had (contracted a fever during the journey, expired ‘at the hospital. He was buried in the afternoon,.a number of British troops marching’ in-the funeral procession.

Major-General Baron Von Slatin Pasha arrivy- ed at Khartoum -on the 29th ulto. on board the 8.S- “Cairo”, returning from his-inspection — tour in KAssala Province by way of Sings and | Hillet Abbas. This tour extended over a period of forty-fine days, ‘during which Slatin Pasha, accompanied by his private secretary, Ibrahim Eff. Dimitri, travelled’on camel back a distance of more than eleven hundied miles. ~
Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Educa- tion, leaves Cairo to-day, a _ Egypt on.a tour of inspection. *
Sir William and Lady Richmond have lett England for, Egypt, and will be absent for two or three months. -
Miralai May Bey has arrivedat Cairo in order to take charge of ‘the Cairo branch of the Finance Department. —
Lady Glyn and Miss S. Blant have left | Bureote, near Abingdon, for Egypt, and will . return to England in May.
Lady- Wilhelmina Brooke and her daughter are spending the winter in Cairo.
Mrs. Geddes, Mrs. Stewart Geddes, and Miss Geddes are due at Port-Said to-morrow . by the P. & O. SS. “Egypt.” ;
Mr. Robert Endicott, brother of. Mrs. Joseph Chamberlain, who is spending a few days in Italy is coming to Egypt.

Mr. R. Whitwort-Josea| the special corres- pondent of the “Daily Telegraph” in Cairo, and formerly editor ofthe nowdefanct “Oriental ' Daily News” has left Cairo for Alexandria and he’ will embark on the 9th inst. a 8.8, “Heliopolis” for England.
Bimbashi Bethell has been promoted: Kaima- kam and appointed second in command of the Artillery and Assistant Director of Ordnance.
Lieutenant R. B. J. Smith, Coldstream Guards, is coming out to Egypt with the rein- p | forcementshortly to besent to — stationed here.
Lieut. J. B. M. Mattheire Denslieon, ‘gnd Batt: Inniskilling Fusiliers’ has been attached to the Headquarters staff.
Lieut and Assistant ‘Comm iseaty of Ordtan: ce A. Sargeant is under orders to embark oa duro asap ern anor liane Orinda S Bese iy Mr, Sega lps. daty at — Kasrel-Nil,

div.head: >TELEGRAMS.
THE FRENCH CABENET.
RECEPTION OF DIPLOMATIC CORPS.
div.p: Panis, January. 4.
The Ministers have been appointed .as an- nounced yesterday. . The Government has de cided to congratulate General Lyantey on the rapidity of the operations against the Beni moassens.

To-day thé Diplomatic Corps ,were received after the adjournment caused by the death of Mr. Guyot Dessaigne. Count Tornielli and Mr. Fallitres. congratplated each other on the important resulta of the Hague . Conference and expressed the hope of future agreement.(Havas)
Panis, January 4.
M. Briand, Minister of Instruction; has been appointed: Minister of Justice. M. Briand’s sucgessor, has nos been. settled. (Reuter )

div.head: THE, GERMAN: SCANDALS.
>HARDEN APPEALS.
div.p: Berum, January 4.
The judge declared that Count Moltke left the court stairtiless. Harden has appealed. (Reuter)

div.head: THE- COTTON — CRISIS.
150,000 OPERATIVES EFFECTED.
div.p: MANCHESTER, January 4. 150,000 operatives will be forthwith affected by the cotton lockoet. There is no indication of sither side yielding. (Reuter)

div.head: CARTRIDGE, SMUGGLING.
EXPLOSION ON BOARD SHIP.
div.p: Atuens, January 5. A.sensation has.been caused. here-by the explosion on the.Italian 8:8..‘‘Montenegro” of a. bag of eaxtzidges consigned to Constantinople and smuggled among the mails. Three persons have been injured. (Reuter0

div.head: KING: OF SWEDEN INTERVIEWED.
div.p: STocKHOLM, January 5. The King, in an interview granted to a Stockholm paper, renounced the coronation as unnecessary and not in accord withthe spirit of the age: For a long time he had regarded the ceremonial of opening Parliament as anti- quated, and which, he said, would be simplified. ( Reuter)

div.head: GUNBOATS FOR GUINEA.
div.p: lisbon, January 5. It ia. deolared here that no expedition is being sent to Guinea at present, but the garri- sons of Bissao and Cacheo are being reinforced. Two-gunboats are going from Loanda.( Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH FOREIGN MINISTER.
div.p: Paris, January 5. . M. Pichon has gone to Madrid for a few days. He will then tour. privately in South Spain. (Renter )

div.head: THE SULTAN. AND . MENELIK.
div.p: ConsTANTINOPLE, January 6. A Decree of the Sultan absolutely refuses | the Abyssinian demands with reference to the | religious question in Palestine. While desirous of being agreeable to Menelik. His Majesty finds it necessary to avoid anything tending to embitter the relations between the churches in Syria. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN FAMINE CREDIT.
div.p: St. Pergrssure, January 4. The famine credit. has been raised to 15,000,000 roubles. (Reuter)

div.p: Matta, January 4.
The Dake and Duchess. of ,Cohnanght. have arrived. . They. received an enthusiastic..wel- come..The warships were, dressed. ‘(Heuter)

div.head: BOMBS IN BARCELONA.
div.p: Barcelona, January 4.

Yesterday a man endeavoured to leave a packet at the Crédit Lyonnais here which was refused. The man departed taking the packet which contained a bomb-which exploded in the street. The man eseaped. There have been 17 bomb ontrages.in the streets here during ‘last year resulting in the death of three persons 21.were wounded. The criminals have not been discdvered.:: The -local ‘deputies are agitating for Government measures for. seonrity.
Royal Decree: .abolishes constitutional guarantees. ( Reuter)

div.head: AMERICA AND JAPAN.
div.p: WasHINaTON, January 4.

The Government has addressed a.’ friendly remonstrance to Japan, owing to the fact that immigration has been increasing despite the informal agreement that it would be virtually prohibited by Japan refusing passports.( Reuter)
Loypon, January 4.

The ‘Tribune’ learns from Washington that President Roosevelt, has authorised .Mr, Root to notify Japan, that it Congress. passes the Japanese Labour, Exclusion Bill he will veto it, The ‘T'ribune” learns from. Vancouver that the immigration of Japanese from Honolaln is increasing. ( Reuter)
Paris, January 5.>

Ambassador Kurino, interviewed. 4° propos of the departure of the American fleet’ for the Pacific, considers that the situation is in no degree aggravated. -Japan ‘might judge as offensive a special legislation» of which" the United States thought nothing at all. (Havas)
Washinaton, January 5.
President Roosevelt and .Messrs. Root,.and Metcalf held a. lengthy. conference on the Japanese situation. ( Réuter )

The receivership for the Chicago Milwaukee | Electric Railway Company has been dismissed. (Reuter)

div.head: >A FROOK ,EXBIBITION.
div.p: A well-known’ Bond, street comtonriére has lately arrived in Cairo in: the person of Mme. Wyatt who is holding an exhibition of her beautiful frocks in, the show’ rooms iof ‘Mme. Brachet in the Sharia Suliman Pasha, opposite the Standard Life Buildings.

Mme Wyatt’s visit to Cairo is with the object of starting a high class business here’ in con- nection with the one she is so ably conducting in London ; and an examination of the Jovely | models she has brought with her © will convince most of us’ that she is supplying a long felt want.

Mme: Wyatt is accompanied by a sister, also an experienced dressmaker, who ‘will re- main throoghout the season. taking orders, measprements and fittings which will be ex: pressed to.London, there to be completed andet Mme Wyatt’s personal supervision and by her own trained staff of assistants. In this way her clientele may be certain of getting the latest modes and freshest materials from both London and Paris, with a certainty of fit which ig ‘not the least of Mme Wyatt’s* many resommeénda- tions.

In comparison; with the bewatifal models she is-, exhibiting, Mme Wyatt's prices are exceedingly- moderate :’ she willaupply simple trocks and, tailor. mades. from seven guineas ; and trom, twelve to twenty :.guineas:, the, most delightful and, dainty: toilettes for both:day and. evening: wear can. be -obtsined:from-her. A. description ‘of ‘a. few- of .these ‘will ishow how .well Mme Wyatt,-has gaaged the. wants of the Cairo mondaine, and how, suitable are her garments to. the requirements of. our season. Most of her :models-are from: Paquin and. other..leading .Rrench houses, -though those of. her: own designing are.equally fas cinating. Nearly all .these . dainty: frocks show the: latest expression of the Empire mo- vement:+-the raised straight waist: line, the front of the waist, the subtle ecolourings,;.and the delicate enibroideries of silk-and lace, and bead and, tissue. which distinguish. the fashions of the moment. In fact «:.visit: te!-Mme Wyatt's exhibition is a revelation and illu- stration of all the best. we have-read ‘of in the latest fashion ‘papers.

A lovely evening gown showing in its folds the veiled fire of the opal, is composed! of several layers of grey chiffon over an under- dress of rosy satin oriental. The clinging skirt meets into.a deep shaped flounce of lace dyed grey, headed by folds-of panne, and is farther ornamented: by long wreaths of flowers and foliage expressed'in dull silver and faint pink tissue. The same glistening embroidery appears upon: the short full bodice which is arranged to show, a’ dainty vest run with row after row of narrow cream valenciennes. The price of this is thirty: guineas;bat it is one of Mmé Wyatt's lovliest models and is well worth:the money.

Among those less expeusive is a dainty little frock-most suitable for a young girl, the soft cream silk bearing a tiny floral device, ‘and. the trimming consisting of bands of silk embroidery outlined by double frills of cream lace. These. bands define the square cut corsage which is softened byes tucked net and lace vest and wreath of tiny roses, and pass down one side of bodice and skirt encircling the latter. Bands ot the narrow black velvet caught by tiny paste buckles keep together the lace on both sleeves and bodice. This frock 1s priced at fifteen guineas ; and for thirteen we noticed a charm- ing old-world’ figured Chené silk of almost fawn colour; trimmed aboat the skirt with square battlements of, narrow ruching; touches of purple velvet, long silk fringe and flat rosettes appearing on the Empire bodice.

Auother evening frock of loveliest design and } marked only twenty-two guineas, is of .pale | | blue over which hangs a Jong straight panelled | Itunic of fine white lace, edged with. broad | bands of guipure “d’Ireland” and_.panne. Heavy motifs “d’Ireland” are, arranged upon the sleeves and bodice which is, a bewildering but entirely fascinating _ medley. of panne,, lace and finely tucked chiffon, canght at the back with a large soft ‘buckle,

One of the most attractive of day frocks ia in cloth ofa new shade—a dull pink with some: thing of terra-cotta in its composition.’ ‘This has the long plain skirt tightly. racked across the front of the waist according to, the faney-of the moment (which the irreverent. terms.the crumb-catcher cnt) and the Japanese’ effect across the shoulders shows wide insertions of heavy lace dyed to match. The, lace..vestand high collar bear, touches of black. .and applica: tion of silky embroidery, .and a. tiny black cravat encircles the throat: To complete this fascinating costume there is an Empire coat of cloth braided: en suite made. with cuta-way fronts and loose short skirt, and the high up- standing collar which is en regle in snch garments.

Another Empire coat whi¢h: can -be slipped on over any dress is of white’ embroidered filet lace with,short sleeves set into .rather. wide}|’ armholes,. This is bordered with. white; ailk braid, straps of black velvet appearing. on.the upstand®ag collar and Jappels,; handsome tassels and ornaments of white.silk giving yet: another finish.

Very pretty is the toilette de visite :ofisevres blue crépe-de-chene of lustrous surface ithd skirt longand plain and devoid of any fulness round the hips. The corsage of coarsely..tucked chiffon is edged with black satin and cut en |! cur to show a vest and collar of filet Jace, the latter bordered by a tiny roffe. A Simalated’ cape bolero of black embroidered filet ‘edged! with black, satin hangs’ from the shoulders, and the high draped sash finishes swith short tails at the back. Thirteen guineas is the price of this; and there are many others to be noticed at much the same reasonable figure.
These models chien at hazard represent only & few.of these which , are. on-yiew for.the next fortnight or so in Mme. Brachét’s show

rooms. -They.are ll .49 exquisitely fresh and dainty, and of the -moment,that-we-can con- fideutly recommend our readers to judge for themselves by paying Mme Wyatta visit at their earliest convenience.

div.head: THE WHITE NILE.
ITS VALUE TO EGYPT.
div.p: To tHe Eprror oF THE “Eayprian Gazerre.”

Dear Sir,~-Since giving my lecture at the last meeting of the Khedivial Geographical society Ihave gone more thoroughly into the question of the levels of the White Nile and have found that the White Nile is of more’ value to Egypt than the Rand gold deposits are to the Transvaal. If we take the highest flood level at ‘Khartoum at 0 metres, we have :—at Renk, 500 kilo- metres above Khartoum, still 0 metres, at the Saubat mouth 840 kilometres above Khartoufh still 3.50.metres, at Lake No—mouth, 970 kilo- metres above Khartoum, still 4.75 metres. In other words we have tor half the distance a level lake and for the other half a slope of 1/100,000, or for the whole distance. a slope of 1/200,000.

These fighres are of extraordinary interest to Egypt. ‘They mean that reservoir barrages could be built at Khartoum, at any place between Khartoum and the Saubat-month like the Abu Zeid bar, and at the Saubat month. Such barrages, would form reservoirs capable of storing over 7-milliards: of .cubic metres of water and settling for ever the summer supply question for Egypt and the Sudan. These barrages morever could be built ih three years at a cost under £3,000,000.

The Government to-day has it in its power to put an end to the depression which is weighing on Egypt, and to put life into every land enterprise in: Egypt and. the Sudan. | began my 1894 Teport with the words. “Of all the methods which Egypt has ever employed for the increase of her material:wealth, there is only one which has never « failed her. Whenever the country has turned-to the Nile it has not been disappointed.” 1 repeat them to-day.

It will be possible to so control the waters of the White Nile thatthe summer supplies, of the Nile will be greater than the winter supplies and the Nile willbecome likethe Tigris and the Euphrates, those typical rivers of peren- nial irrigation whose summer supplies are in excess of their winter supplies, and’ where perennial irrigation had its birth and flourished for thonsands of years and will again.
Yours faithfully,
W. Wixicocks.
Cairo, January 4th.

div.head: DENISHWATI-
div.p: To THe Eprror or THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”
Sir,

Not a few of your readers were ‘struck with amazement at the favorable comments in your coluamna upon the approaching release of the Denishwai convicts. Though conspicuously fair to those who differ from you, the policy of the “Egyptian Gazette” has been hitherto uniform- ly Imperialist. To-endorse the decision ofa Liberal Government, which in this instance was actuated solely by interested motives, reads uncomménly like a dereliction of principle.

Political mémories are proverbially short ; but» most: of us, here in Egypt at all events, have preserved a recollection that the prosecu- tion of the Denishwai villagers arose out of an attack upon British officers in which some were badly injured, and one: of them ost his life. Sir Edward @réy assured the ~House of Com- mons that the..tribunal before which the. trial took place was composed ofthe ablest judges in thé land, and Lord Cromer expressed his opinion that~the~ sentences “were just and necessary.” For what reason, then, are the convicts to be liberated ? The Liberal Govern- ment, puta it on the-ground of clemency. But clemencyis a luxury which from past experience has cost our country dear. It was an act of clemency indulged in by Mr. Gladstone after the reverse of our arms at Majuba Hill which necessitated the second Boer War with all its attendant suffering, privation and carnage and the expenditure by the British Exchequer of two hundred aud fifty million pounds.
Absit omen!

Do not let: us deceive ourselves with any such clap-trap sentiment. No one who has intelligently followed current events is likely to be misled by it. For all the tall taik there is no clemency in this case—not the semblance of it The convicts owe their freeduin_ to one fact and to one fact alone - fear. Fear, yot of anything that might happen in Exypt—there is happily no cause for anxiety at the present time —but fear of an adverse vote which might hurl the Government from power. His Majesty’s present advisers, with. the. largest majority ever obtained in our-time, cannot rely upon their own supporters. It is not considerations of mercy which weigh with them. The dictates of humanity have played no part in their deliberations, The truth is that they.have not the courage of their professed convictions. Their wire-pullers have told them that the continued ‘incarceration of the Denishwai convicts renders their position perilously insecure. That. is enough for them. At the bidding of party exigencies they fling consist- ency to the winds. Theirs is an ignominious capitulation: to ‘expediency. That is the long and the short of it.
IMPERIALIST.
Cairo, January 2.

We fail to see how “ Imperialist” can ac- cuse us of inconsistency. In announcing the decision to release the prisoners we stated that it. was anvact of political clemency ofa similar character--to what ie known as the “ King’s Pardon. ”“The decision was obviously arrived at for political reasons and not onits merits, for
>if the latter was the*‘catse it implies the stultification of the Tribunal, which passed judgment on the men and’also on Lord Cromer for supporting the judgment. “The Spectator,” however, remarks :—

If the decision come to was réached on its merits, and not in any degree owing to politic- al pressure, .we may express our satisfaction that the authorities, British and Egyptian, have seen their way to exercise that right of clemency which should exist in every executive |, Government for tempering in exceptional circumstances the course of justice. At the same time, we cannot pretend -to think that the crime for which the prisoners were sentenc- ed was anything but participation in a murder ofa peculiarly brutal kind. Wedo not forget that the assailants of the British officers dragged them out ofthe carriages in which they had taken refuge, beat them when they lay on the ground and, further, robbed their bodies. None of these acts are consistent with the theory that the officers. were killed or in- jured in the course of the natural and legiti- mate effort of the peasants to prevent their pigeons being shot by trespassers on the vil- lage lands. The officers were no doubt in the wrong, though they were not aware’of the fact, in interfering with the property of the natives, We cannot, however, hold that so mild a violation of the rights of property gives either black men or white men the right to kill without being. held responsible. for their acts. We should say exactly the same if in sithilar circumstances an Englisman beat a native to death who entered his. garden, trampled'down his flower-beds, and: destroyed his vegetables.

div.head: COMPANY PROCEDURE IN. EGYPT.
div.p: To THE Epiror oF THE “Eayprian -GaZeTre.”

Sir,~—A few days since you. published a letter from a correspondent,Mr Gooding, under the above heading, asking to be informed if such: an article as that which he quotes, is imposed as. a usual ‘and customary condition under which shareholders are invited to sus- cribe capital for joint stock’ companies. I am surprised that Mr. Gooding should ask this question,-or that it should be thought neces- sary to refer to London for @ reply. If Mr. Gooding will only ‘read the Companies Act, 1862, section 67. he will find the following words, which are a complete ariswer to his question : —
‘‘All acts done by such directors & c. shall be deemed to be valid, notwithstanding- avy defect that may afterwards be discovered in their appointments or qualifications.”

This is the law on the question‘raised by Mr. Gooding, whether it forms part of the Articles of Association of any Limited Liability Com- pany or not, and the article of which Mr. Gooding complains so much, is only a rough translation of'the law, and means*neither more or less, and if did, it would be valid.

In common with most. other people knowing anything~about—English—company law, I was much astonished during last autumn, to see that the shareholders of a local English com- pany were convened at a general meeting and asked to confirm the previous acts of their directors, because it was discovered that they might not have been duly qualified, and that, without any suspicion whatever that their acts were not perfectly “bona-fide.”’
It is only necessary to refer to the law as above quoted, to see that such a proceeding was perfectly unnecessary and uncalled for.

Soch questions nearly always turn on. the due deposit of a share qualification. Now in ail the Acts. forming: the law of Limited Liability from 1862 to 1907, no such qualifica- tion is required, but if, as is.’usually -the case, it is.required, and rightly so, by the Articles of Association of any Company, it must be respected. But the Legislator who drew up the Act of 1862, wisely saw, that unless he made*some such provision as that contained in section 67 above referred to, the unfortunate shareholders .of Limited) Companies, would never have been able to find out when anything connected with their business was’ definitely settled, and their most importart - affairs might have-been, at any moment thrown into a state of chaos, on’ the. slightest grounds, bys the unscropulous holder of a single share.

Many of the provisions of the manifold Acts from 1862 to 1901 have been. hitherto. but little respected, becaise no very definite penalty was attached to their observance, but now we have the Act of the 28th Angnst 1907 which improves and very clearly defines, a large number of penalties, hitherto unheard of. It is true that its penal clausesde not. come into force until the Ist of July 1908, so that we are still given some time to put our house in order, and those who. are wise will not neglect to do so before that date.
Yours truly, A Dtrscror.
Alexandria, January 3:

div.head: >POLO.
div.p: ~ ‘The final for the Khartoum Challenge Cup took place on Friday: 27th December. Six teams competed, the Staff steam proving the win- ners. When congratilating the winning team, Hi E. the Govenor: General said that the challenge cup had ’. been “presented by Colonel Markham and the Officers of the Ist Battalion of. the King’s Royal Rifle Corps as a souvenir of their stay at Khartoum’ and*as*a:token of | regard and friendship for their comrades‘in the Khartoum Garrison. and in. -the.. Sudan Government with .whom they had often had many good and hard: games of polo’ on. this ground. He considered it -hardlynecessary to say on behalf of the Khartoum*Polo Club how much they, appreciated :the kindlyfeeliags which’ had. promptedi.their..comrades | inetthe Rifles to present» this Challenge’ Cup. «The keeriness which had*been shown during thé last few days matches was a strong proof—if- any proof were needed—of the rivalry between the various teams to obtain the honour of holding this much coveted trophy.

He was confident-that the kind donors would be much interested in hearing’ the result of therfirst year's competition for the cup, and he intended, with the permission of the Polo Club, to write to Colonel Markhamandiheg,him to accept himself and eonvey-to-his officers their warm appreciation of the gift which—if*the recent matches were to be taken as an earnest! of the future—would be annually competed.for with the greatest keennessj and-would-tend to stimulate friendly: rivalry amongst the various teams and lead to generally raising and im- proving the standard of play. He coneluded by, calling on all. present >to .congratelate«the winningAeanr-on having successfallpearried off this Challenge Cup, and called for*three theers which were heartily given (“Sudan Times”)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA. BOURSE.
div.p: Lundi. 6 Janvier.

La tenne qui s’était beaucoup améliorée ver. dredi dernier est redevenue a peu de choses prée ce qu'elle était auparavant. On attribue cette réaction & : la baiase assez notable qui ‘gest produite ce matin sur les cotons égyp- tiens. Le fait est que la plupart des fluctuations indiquent un reoul plus ou moins margné, Au gurplus les transactions sont restées limitées a une petite catégorie de titres, entre autres l’Agricole, la National Bank, lobligation Oré- dit Foncier et le Comptoit La Cassa di Sconto, qui a jouid’un moment de faveur & Youverture od elle a été traitée aux environs de 50 1/?, est revenue en cléture 4 49 1/2, soit en définitive | en avance de 1 franc sur le dernier cours.

En raison d’une demande active et: snivie V Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier a continué ga marche ascendante de 274 a 276, acheteurs; la nouvelle, au contraire, qui-avait assez bien résisté a la dépression de naguére, a faibli ce matin de 261 }..250 } soas le poids des offres. La National Bank était également offerte. Quant an Comptoir, des ventes l'on ramené de 2 3/16 4 115/16 action et de-1 1/441 1/8 la part de fondateur. O’est, comme on le voit, la variation la plus sensationnelle du jour.
Apres ce que nous venons-de dire on congoit que la tendance soit plutdt pour la faiblesse-

La National Bank fiéchit de 201/4 a 20 8/16, la Delta Light de 9 13/32.4 9 3/8,les Lots Tarcs de 165 & 164, la Land Bank de 7 1/84 7 et la Banque d’Orient de 114 2-113. D’autre part, l’Alexandria. Water progresse de 10 3/8 & 10 1/2et les Jonissances Eaux du Caire de 177 & 178.

Parmi les titres de moindre importance, ls Delta Land recule de 1 1/16 a1 1/82, P’Ordi- nary Khedivial Mail de 17/9 & 17/6,les Estates de 3/8 411/32, ’Urbaine de 2 15/16 a2 7/8, l’Allotment de 2 & 1 15/16 l’action et de 45 4 42 P.T-. la fondateur, la Port-Said Salt de 11/- & .10/-» les Ritz Hotels de 13/82 a 3/8,la Fanous de 3/164 1/8 et la Levico de 5/16 a 9/32. Seuls Aboukir avance-de 28/3 & 28/6 et les Cotton Ginners de 1 1/4 & 1 9/32.
Pour la plupart de ces valeurs les prix sont purement nominaux, n’étant déterminés en général que par des offres ou demandes sans contre-partie.

Dans uné réunion tenue le 5 Janvier, 1908, 3 Alexandrie au Siége de l’Association des Courtiers en Valeurs et sur linitiative do Comité de la dite Association, ila été décidé de fonder une Association de défense des inté- réts des actionnaires égyptiens, sur les bases suivantes :
A) L’Association entreprend avant tout une ceuvre de conservation et de présefvation de la fortune publique.
B) Les membres de !’Association doivent tre établis dans le pays.

C) Loraque le Comité décidera d’exercer une action en justice, cette action sera intentée au nom des intéresaés eux-mémes et ceux-ci de- vront s’engager 4 verser une provision dont: le taux sera fixé par le Comité.
Dans ces limites, voici le programme som- maire de l’Agsociation-et de son Comité :
i° Etudier la situation dés Sociétés Anony- mes Egyptiennes et étrangéres dont les titres sont l'objet dé transactions aux Bourses d’Alex andrie et du Caire.
2° Provoquer des explications amiables des | Conseils d’Administration de: ces sociétés.
3° Instituer un bureau d’études ob tous les renseignements utiles Aconnaltre concernant les sociétés nouvelles et anciennes seront réunis.
4° Former un Conseil de Contentieux.

5° Accueillir-tes’ plaintes motivées des ac- tionnaires adhérents et leur apporter, le cas échéant et aprés enquéte complate, an concours matériel et moral ; dans ce but, pro- voquer des réunions officienses des actionnaires et porter, ‘s'il y alieu, leurs décisions reconnues légitimes, devant les Assemblées légalement convoquées et au besoin devant les juridictions compétentes égyptiennes ou étrangéres.
Il est entendu que le Comité restera maitre d’étendre son action dans les limites de la dé- fense des actionnaires.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
SERVICE DES RECETTES

Dans‘ lé courant du mois de Janvier’ de chaque année, tout possesseur d’animaux et véhicules prévus par l’arrété du 21 Oct, 1905, doit faire personnellement la déclaration des animaux et véhicules qu’il posséde, sous peine d’une double imposition 4 titre d’amende.
Cette déclaration devra étre faite de la ma- niére suivante :
Elle portera sur tous les animaux et véhbi- cules quele possesseur posséde pour la pre- miére fois ;

Si cette premiére déclaration est déja faite, lobligation du possesseur se bornera,'par suite, & aviser la Municipalité, dans le délaiprécité, des changements survenus dans le nombre ‘ou la nature des animaux et yéhioules déclarés.
Il n’y aura pas lieu de renouveler la déclara- tion si aucun changement n’est survenu.
Pour les animaux et vébioules recus dans le courant de |’année, le possesseur en devra éga- lement, sous la méme peine, faire la déclaration dans les dix jours de la réception.

A partir da premier février de chaque année | aura lieu un recensement en vuede vérifier exactitude des déclarations des contribuables, sans préjadice du droit de la Municipalité de réitérer 88 vérifications: & toute époque de Yannée.
L’Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Cuataway. 31638-8-i.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Mercredi 8 Janvier 1908 de 10. heures du matin A midi, la Municipalité procédera 4 la vente aux enchéres publiques prés: de la Porte Rosette d’une quantité de pierres (Kan- taris, Moéllons, Dekchoum) \ provenant de la 2 démolition des fortifications Sud,
Ces pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 & 100 M3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d’en- chérede 1 % et déposer le 10% dela valeur de la marchandise achetée au. moment de la i vente et effectuer le paiement intégral 4 la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de adjudication. |

Ils auront 4 supporter les droits de carniére au profit de la Ville et devront enlever. les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de Vadjudicataire et de perte du dépot de 10 %.
L’ Administrateur “Signe” W. P. Cuataway. Alexandrie, le 8 Janvier 1908. 31670-3-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Liste ELecTORALE GENERALE MUNICIPALE pouR L’ANNEE 1908.

Le publie est inforiné que la liste électorale municipale pour l'année 1908 est affiehée du lerau 15 Janvier 1908 au Gouvernorat, & la Bourse Khédiviale-et & la Municipalité, ot toute personne.pourta la consulter.

Les personnes qui auraient des réclamations & faire, pourront les: présenter jusqa’au 31 Janvier 1908.a Mr.Jle Vice-Président de la Commission Municipale lequel en: réftrera a cette Assemblée qui statuera en dernier ressort.
En cas dedemande d'inscription, les per- sonnes intéressées devront produire les justifi- cations nécessaires (quittances de lataxe da 20.0 ete.)
Des formules imprimées sont & la disposition des réclamanta 4 la Municipalité.
Le Gouverneur de la Ville d’Alexandrie | M. Ipapt. Alexandrie, le 31 Décembre 1907. 31637-3-1

div.p: L’Express Nile Steamers Compaty. a l’hon: neur ‘de prévenir le Public que Monsieur Oscar Emsheimer ne fait plus partie dé son personne! depuis le 4 Janvier courant.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
